Interviewer
Hello and welcome everyone. I'm Corey Hofstein and this is Flirting with Models, the podcast that pulls back the curtain to discover the human factor behind the quantitative strategy. Corey Hofstein is the co-founder and chief investment officer of Newfound Research. Due to industry regulations, he will not discuss any of Newfound Research's funds on this podcast. All opinions expressed by podcast participants are solely their own opinion and do not reflect the opinion of Newfound Research. This podcast is for informational purposes only and should not be relied upon as a basis for investment decisions. Clients of Newfound Research may maintain positions and securities discussed in this podcast. For more information, visit thinknewfound.com. In many ways, the topic of conversation for this episode revolves around what ultimately amounts to a fairly vanilla, almost index-like portfolio. The asset class in question, however, may verge on the exotic for listeners with less fluency in the field of derivatives. My guest is Eric Ervin, President and CEO of RealityShares, and he has joined me to discuss their flagship ETF, Divi. I would argue that Divi is one of the few exposures that truly fits the definition of being both liquid and alternative. By tapping into the OTC market, Eric and his team build a portfolio of one-to-five-year dividend swaps, which have historically earned investors a unique return, known as the dividend risk premium. Eric's confidence to bring such a unique product into the market was born from his experience as an advisor, where he utilized alternatives extensively with his clientele. Learning more about this experience in evaluating alternatives and the mental framework he used that allowed him to allocate upwards of 50% of client portfolios is where we begin our conversation. Eric, thank you for joining me today.

Customer

What you think is a risk reducer may not be. It may be a risk enhancer and a return reducer, unfortunately. We would allocate about 50 to 60% of our clients assets in alternatives by the traditional sense. 当然。我想我可能会按时间顺序来回顾，讲述我们，或者说我是如何从A点走到今天的，同时也作为一名顾问，分享我的一些不同的投资哲学和策略。而且，由于我身处西海岸，这里创造的财富大多不是资本市场财富。更多的是有人建立了一家企业，有人构建了一个公司结构，有人参与了一家被出售的公司，或者他们建立了一个庞大的房地产帝国。因此，我在摩根士丹利的客户，我从90年代中期开始，见证了互联网泡沫的膨胀并经历了那段时期。但客户们并不喜欢资本市场。为什么我要把所有的财富都投入到资本市场和现代投资组合理论中呢？而且，当市场下跌18%时，你告诉我你只下跌了17%，这并不是胜利。这种情况下，自然会倾向于另类投资，并为客户创造一种绝对回报策略，因为我知道我能够做到这一点。我会在多年的时间里不断失败，客户也知道这一点，但至少我们正在尝试做出改变，并在投资组合中构建不同类型的风险。客户能够理解这一点。因此，在这样做的时候，你几乎经历了一个进化过程，从最初的“好吧，让我们做流动性另类投资，因为它们不同，它们能带来改变”，但很快我发现，它们在很多情况下只是高价的国库券。最终，它们要么过度分散，不应该真的被包装在流动性产品中，因为真正的价值可能是杠杆的使用或其他方面，要么它们只有一个吸引人的名字，但实际上并没有一个吸引人的策略。所以，真正重要的是学会深入挖掘。我天生就有一种工程背景，这种背景已经融入了我的DNA。就像我11岁时拆解烤面包机一样，我只是真的想理解事物。因此，我会拆解这些不同的策略，并试图理解回报可能来自哪里，知道其中很多是虚假的对冲基金、私募股权。现在，那里有一些有趣的东西，因为你可能会有更多有趣的策略，而且我们的客户相对更富有。他们不是亿万富翁类型的客户，但他们拥有500万到5亿美元的净资产。因此，我们能够使用许多具有较长锁定期和较长流动性条款的独特策略。再次，我想要理解其中的每一个细节，并真正理解其价值主张。这归结为我如何分配我的资产？我是否分配股票、债券、另类投资，或者我的债券对冲基金是否真的不是债券策略，也许它不是另类投资。什么是另类投资？这是一个广泛的领域。因此，我们真正要做的是风险降低和回报增强。例如，一个高度杠杆化的债券对冲基金可能是回报增强者，而不是风险降低者或股票。所以我不能把对冲基金仅仅看作是风险降低者，而不是回报增强者。所以我不能把它们看作是股票或债券。现在，我可以将整个投资世界分成这两个不同的类别。如果我是对的，有时真正的技巧在于判断正确。你认为的风险降低者可能不是，它可能是风险增强者和回报降低者，不幸的是。这真的是我得出的前提和哲学，虽然犯了很多错误。但我们还是会分配股票和债券。我认为这是一个非常好的主意。我们通常会将客户资产的50%到60%分配在传统意义上的另类投资中。对我们来说，这并不疯狂，因为它实际上只是在回报增强者和降低者之间进行60-40的混合分配。

Customer
Yeah, it's interesting too because, again, it kind of has to be an evolution where then the conviction has to be there. And I think as most advisors, myself included, you start with 2% allocation and then you're left with the riskiest of the alternatives because otherwise you're never going to get the payoff. You have to have some massive asymmetry and you start to get a stigma of alternatives. Those are high risk. But in reality, if you're allocating strategies that are designed to produce 5% to 7% returns on average over time with a very low standard deviation, you can't necessarily allocate just 2% or 3% to that because when the market sells off and your 60-40 portfolio blows up, it didn't help at all. So you have to have a more meaningful allocation there. So that's step one is, hey, what are we trying to do? Are we trying to just be with the market? And if so, then you're going to be. Pissed at me when the market blows up because you say it now that you're comfortable with that. And yet when the market does blow up, you're going to be upset. But if we're trying to actually be different than the market, then we have to invest differently. And so that was the first thing is getting them with that. And then the second is understanding that these strategies, really understanding them and getting to the bottom of them and knowing who these managers are and knowing what their risk limit and their leverage limits and all of where is the real return coming from? Like merger arb is a great example. There's about 350 to 400 deals announced every year. The typical merger arb manager will invest in all of them. They'll earn about 300 basis points of spread on average of that kind of risk that they're offering. And they'll lever it up massively and earn a decent return until it blows up as an overall strategy. But there were certain managers who really focused on no leverage, finding the deals that are going to go and actually shorting the deals that are most likely to break. But the market's not pricing it in because of that. It's just inefficient. So there were these little opportunities where you could genuinely add value. And the clients loved that. They loved that you were investing their assets in something that was trying to make a difference, not always going to win, but at least somewhat understandable in how it worked. And if you could articulate that value to the client, then I think it worked well for us. In fact, we won a lot of business just as an advisor. Certainly like investing in 08 during the big housing crisis. That was amazing. We were short subprime through a lot of different managers. And it was like the best time ever. And the world was melting down and we were winning month after month after month. So that was kind of a need.

是的，这也很有趣，因为这必须是一个逐步演化的过程，其中信念必须存在。我认为，像大多数顾问一样，包括我自己，你一开始可能会分配2%的资金，然后你剩下的就是最具风险性的替代方案，因为否则你永远无法获得回报。你必须有一些巨大的不对称性，并且你会开始对替代方案产生偏见。那些是高风险的。但实际上，如果你分配的策略旨在在长时间内平均产生5%到7%的回报，并且标准差非常低，你不能仅仅分配2%或3%，因为当市场下跌时，你的60-40投资组合崩溃了，这根本无济于事。因此，你必须在那里进行更有意义的分配。所以第一步是，嘿，我们试图做什么？我们只是试图跟随市场吗？如果是这样，那么你将会在市场崩溃时对我感到愤怒，因为你说你现在对此感到舒适。然而，当市场真的崩溃时，你会感到不安。但如果我们试图与市场不同，那么我们必须进行不同的投资。所以第一件事是让他们接受这一点。然后第二步是真正理解这些策略，深入了解它们，了解这些经理是谁，了解他们的风险限制和杠杆限制，以及真正的回报来自哪里？比如合并套利就是一个很好的例子。每年大约有350到400笔交易宣布。典型的合并套利经理会投资于所有这些交易。他们平均会从他们提供的这种风险中赚取大约300个基点的利差。他们会大量杠杆化，并赚取不错的回报，直到作为一个整体策略崩溃。但有一些经理真正专注于无杠杆，寻找那些会成功的交易，并实际上做空那些最有可能破裂的交易。但市场没有考虑到这一点，因为它是低效的。所以有一些小机会，你可以在那里真正增加价值。客户喜欢这样。他们喜欢你将他们的资产投资于试图产生差异的东西，虽然不一定总是赢，但至少在运作方式上是可理解的。如果你能向客户阐明这种价值，那么我认为这对我们来说效果很好。事实上，作为顾问，我们赢得了很多业务。当然，比如在2008年大住房危机期间投资。那真是太棒了。我们通过许多不同的经理做空次贷。那是一生中最好的时光。世界正在崩溃，而我们每个月都在赢。所以那是一种需要。

Customer
It's funny, we were just talking about merger ARB, and so there was a manager, John Paulson, who now is very popular and very famous. We had a lot of capital with their merger ARB fund, and they had another fund that was a little bit of an event-driven arbitrage, but mainly strategy. And from there, we started to learn an awful lot more about the asset class. We learned about all the different managers that were trading in the space, and we allocated very heavily. I remember calling clients and saying, I know what I'm about to tell you is ridiculous and crazy, but we need to go big on this. We were buying through Paulson and Passport and several of the other funds that we used. Really neat time to kind of be in the business.

有趣的是，我们刚刚在谈论并购套利（Merger ARB），当时有一位经理，约翰·保尔森（John Paulson），现在他非常受欢迎且声名显赫。我们当时在他们并购套利基金中投入了大量资金，他们还有一个稍微偏向事件驱动套利的基金，但主要还是策略性的。他们是那种能够准确识别哪些交易最有可能完成、哪些交易最有可能破裂的优秀资金管理者。他们的业绩记录非常好，但并不是出类拔萃，只是非常稳健，我们多年来一直与他们合作投资。大约在2006年，他们开始讨论寻找一种方式来做空房地产市场。然后次贷危机浮现，做空抵押债务债券（CDOs），而我作为我，不得不深入研究这个领域，我学到了所有相关的知识。我能够给信用违约互换（Credit Default Swap）定价，我真正地……我的意思是，我完全被这个交易吸引，尤其是潜在回报的不对称性。从那时起，我们开始更深入地了解这个资产类别。我们了解了所有在这个领域交易的经理人，并且我们非常重仓配置。我记得给客户打电话时说，我知道我即将告诉你的事情听起来很荒谬和疯狂，但我们需要在这个交易上大举投入。客户会说，你从未说过这样的话，但哇。我当时想，好吧，如果你有如此坚定的信念。幸运的是，这确实带来了相当不错的回报。但归根结底，这都归结于数学。所有的决策都基于数学。你知道潜在的负回报是3%。我们通过保尔森和Passport以及其他几个我们使用的基金购买了信用违约互换，这些我们明知价值为零的东西，因为我们能看到底层资产。想象一下，这几乎就像一个ETF，你知道里面的资产价值是多少，但如果这个ETF的交易价格是资产价值的100倍，你还能以100美元的价格购买看跌期权。这真是令人惊叹。那真是一个非常棒的时期，能够在金融行业中经历这一切。

Interviewer
Eric, I want to start with basics here and build up from there. Can you walk us through what a swap is, then what a dividend swap is and how dividends swaps relate to the Divi portfolio?

埃里克，我想从基础开始，逐步深入。你能为我们解释一下什么是掉期，什么是股息掉期，以及股息掉期与Divi投资组合的关系吗？

Customer
A swap is nothing more than a financial agreement between two parties. Typically, these are financial institution to institutional investor of swapping an agreed upon asset over time. So over some period of time, there's interest rate swaps, there's lots of different types of swaps, but that's all it is. So you can swap two assets over time with one another. The dividend swap itself is one of the easier swaps to get your brain around because it's based on a pretty simple concept. If the dividends per share of an asset, the market, a stock, anything, are a number, let's just say in the case of the S&P 500, which is really where we focus and we see a lot of value, the dividends per share of the S&P 500 are approximately $53 today and will be this year. We will agree to swap the growth of those dividends or the decline of those dividends for a fixed value, say $53. So I'm going to set a price with you. You and I are going to agree to pay one year from now the dividend of the S&P 500 and you're going to pay me 50 or I'm going to pay you 53 and you're going to pay me either whatever the dividends rise to or whatever the dividends fall to. That's the floating leg of that swap. So it's the realized value of dividends. So whatever dividends are realized to be versus the current implied value, which is what you and I agree on as the price. Those two terms are pretty important. With Divi, the ETF and the way we manage this strategy, what we do is we allocate and again with the dividend swaps, you can actually allocate any time between one year, two years, three years, all the way out 10 years on the S&P 500. What Divi finds to be the kind of that sweet spot of that is the zero to five year term. And we try to equally wait between one, two, three and four years. And then we just roll that first year dividend swap on the S&P 500 out every year. So with that kind of equal allocation, the zero to five year timeframe, we have this nice portfolio. We invest all the capital that comes in into T-bills and use that as the collateral for this dividend swap portfolio. And we end up with a beta to the market or a kind of an overall standard deviation, quite low with a nice decent return, but about a point three.

互换本质上不过是两方之间的金融协议。通常，这是金融机构与机构投资者之间在一段时间内交换约定的资产。所以在某个时间段内，有利率互换，有多种不同类型的互换，但本质上就是如此。你可以在一段时间内相互交换两种资产。股息互换本身是较容易理解的互换之一，因为它基于一个相当简单的概念。如果一项资产的每股股息，比如市场、股票等，是一个数值，我们以标普500为例，这是我们关注的重点，我们看到了很多价值，标普500的每股股息大约是53美元，今年也将是这个数值。我们将同意交换这些股息的增长或下降，以一个固定值，比如53美元。所以我要和你设定一个价格。你和我将在一年后同意支付标普500的股息，你要支付我50美元，或者我支付你53美元，然后你要支付我股息上涨或下跌的实际金额。这就是互换的浮动部分。所以这是股息的实际价值。无论股息实际达到多少，与当前我们约定的隐含价值相比。这两个术语非常重要。通过Divi，这个ETF以及我们管理这种策略的方式，我们所做的是分配，再次强调，通过股息互换，你实际上可以在一年、两年、三年，一直到十年之间分配标普500的股息。Divi发现那个甜蜜点是零到五年的期限。我们尝试在一年、两年、三年和四年之间平均分配。然后我们每年都将标普500的第一年股息互换滚动出去。通过这种平均分配，零到五年的时间框架，我们有了这个不错的投资组合。我们将所有进来的资本投资于国库券，并将其用作这个股息互换投资组合的抵押品。最终，我们得到了一个相对于市场的贝塔值或总体标准差，相当低，但回报不错，大约是1.3个百分点。

Interviewer
Hey listeners, Cory here. Please pardon the interruption, but before we dive deeper into the realm of dividend swaps, I wanna try to provide a bit of intuition. Whenever I'm trying to understand a new and complex topic, I often try to start with the limits. For dividend swaps, the two obvious extremes are an infinitely length perpetual swap and a bullet one-year swap. In the case of the perpetual swap, the floating leg receives all future dividends of the index, which under basic financial theory, the net present value of all those dividends is simply equal to the current index price, which also tells us the value of the fixed leg. Since the index price is equal to the net present value of all future dividends, any increase in index price implies that future dividends had been underestimated, while any decrease in index price implies that they had been overestimated. Therefore, mark-to-market value of the swap over time should simply be equal to the difference between the current and the future dividends. The investor is holding the floating leg is effectively long the index and all its associated risks and would expect to earn the equity risk premium over time. On the opposite end of the spectrum, we have a bullet one-year swap. In this case, the floating leg only bears the risk of the realized dividends accrued over the next year. While the forecast accuracy of realized dividends over a one-year horizon is empirically fairly accurate, investors are only going to be able to see the floating leg over time. Investors willing to bear these risks are compensated with what's called the dividend risk premium. We can use these two extremes to develop a first-order approximation of how we would expect intermediate length dividend swaps to behave. We would expect longer swaps to exhibit more equity sensitivity, while shorter duration swaps would exhibit more sensitivity to uncertainty in short-term dividends. And with that out of the way, back to our regularly scheduled programming. Eric, can you provide some basic intuition around what the dividend risk premium

Okay, so to do this properly, what we first need to do is take a step back and look at what's happening in the derivatives market. All derivatives based on the future price of an instrument, so options, put options, call options, futures contracts, forward contracts, anything that's based on the future price of an instrument is predominantly driven by one thing, which is the price of that instrument. So now fast forward to structured product issuance. So now fast forward to structured product issuance. Again, they're in the business of issuing instruments and hedges and forward transactions on the market as a whole, on the price of the market. And then these dividends become kind of the byproduct or the scraps on the factory room floor that they're willing to sell off in order to continue their main line of business, which is creating structured products on the market as a whole. It's estimated that some $270 billion of structured products are issued every year just in Europe alone on the market, on the price. That leaves these banks with, again, a very small fraction of that in terms of dividend risk. The fees generated on that $270 billion are far in excess of whatever haircut that they'd be willing to take on their dividend risk. And again, that goes back to just the gross notional size of the structured product issuance versus the small notional size of the dividend swap or the dividend risk that they need to hedge in order to do more structured products. And that's kind of how we get into this oversupply of dividend swaps, which is a relatively small market versus the massive demand for structured product issuance, which can create this kind of supply demand imbalance in the dividend swap market. It's good for investors, obviously, and we believe it will continue far into the future. And even when it doesn't, again, you still have this, there is a risk to owning dividends. And so there will still be demand to sell off that risk again for the offset. And so that's kind of a fat tail event or other things like that. So we believe it's persistent and it will likely continue into the future.

好的，要正确地进行这项工作，我们首先需要做的是退一步，看看衍生品市场正在发生什么。所有基于某一工具未来价格的衍生品，如期权、看跌期权、看涨期权、期货合约、远期合约等，主要由一件事情驱动，那就是该工具的价格。这是我们都了解的，也是我们在交易或投资该工具时大多数人所考虑的。但除此之外，它还基于另外两件事。一是利率风险，这很容易对冲。然后是第三件事，如果不使用股息互换，对冲它是非常困难的，甚至是不可能的，那就是股息风险。因为如果你考虑股票支付股息时，它们不断地除息。如果你有权获得这些股票或指数的未来价格，那么你将有权获得除股息之外的所有东西，这些股息将在现在和未来期间支付。所以不管你喜不喜欢，你都在接受这种投资中的股息风险。现在，对于绝大多数在这个市场中投资的人来说，这并不重要，因为他们再次关注的是股票、证券或看涨期权等基础资产的价格变动和价格动量。对。但对于那些在交易中处于另一方并试图提供这些服务的人来说，比如投资银行和资本市场部门，这意义重大。因为那小小的股息部分，如果未对冲，会让他们留下一个不干净的套期保值或不干净的敞口。只要他们没有投入太多资本，这都没问题。但随着资本的不断增长，他们需要消除这种风险。因此，这就是他们创建股息互换市场的原因。这样他们就可以提供或抵消这种风险。通过将这种风险出售给养老金、捐赠基金和其他对冲基金环境。实际上，股息互换市场的开始是为了完成现货价格、未来价格、利率这个三角形，我们已经有了这些。然后最后，中间的股息，也就是股息互换，真正完成了这个三角形，并创建了一个完全对冲的远期交易。所以现在快进到结构化产品的发行。再次，他们在整个市场上发行工具、套期保值和远期交易，基于市场价格。然后这些股息成为他们愿意出售的副产品或工厂车间地板上的废料，以便继续他们的主要业务，即在整个市场上创建结构化产品。据估计，仅在欧洲，每年就有约2700亿美元的结构化产品发行，基于市场价格。这使得这些银行在股息风险方面留下了非常小的部分。从这2700亿美元中产生的费用远远超过他们愿意在股息风险上承担的任何折扣。再次，这回到了结构化产品发行的总名义规模与他们需要对冲以进行更多结构化产品的股息互换或股息风险的小名义规模之间的对比。这就是我们如何进入股息互换的供应过剩，这是一个相对较小的市场，与对结构化产品发行的巨大需求相比，这可以在股息互换市场上创造这种供需失衡。这对投资者显然是有利的，我们相信这种情况将持续到未来。即使它不再发生，你仍然有拥有股息的风险。因此，仍然会有需求来再次出售这种风险以进行抵消。所以这有点像肥尾事件或其他类似的事情。因此，我们相信它是持久的，并且很可能会持续到未来。

首先，风险降低者的概念，任何时候你进入风险降低者的领域，作为批发商或产品，你必须承担更大的举证责任，对吧？因为你现在要求我在这个我不太了解的奇特且深奥的策略中投入更多资金。因此，我需要做更多的研究。如果是收益增强者，我可以分配较小的金额，如果我判断正确，仍然可以获得收益。这是策略的问题。所以现在我必须做更多的工作。那么，这个风险降低策略中是否有杠杆？这是一个大问题。在这种情况下，我们希望确认没有杠杆，实际上也确实如此。因为通常我们看到的风险降低策略或多或少都使用了杠杆。你真的需要理解投资组合以及你在杠杆什么。然后是时间框架？在这里，我们没有太长的时间。Divi已经存在一段时间了，所以我们有足够的时间去验证和观察市场上的真实资金。活跃的分配、赎回、创建，我们经历了各种不同的环境，包括英国脱欧。我们有机会观察它。所以现在这是一个福音。在第一天，这是一个更难理解的产品。你需要花时间去理解它并观察它的交易。所以现在至少我们有一些历史。但这历史并不长。所以下一步是，好吧，现在我们如何深入到下一层？理解这些股息，它们如何交易，交易频率如何，谁是另一边的买家，反之亦然，谁是卖家？什么时候一切变得混乱？什么时候市场走向偏差？是什么导致了这些买家和卖家打破他们传统的价值主张关系？所以我认为这是那些因素。然后显然，股息的基本核心是什么？如果他们是对的，如果这个批发商是对的，他告诉我这个产品是基于股息支付流构建和设计的，那么我通常可以根据自己的评估来判断我认为股息会做什么。有很多好的信息。我们在网站上有一套相当强大的研究，包括顾问网站和ETF网站。但如果我能对股息感到满意，并且我能理解，好吧，标普股息可能会继续增长，那么我需要理解交易环境和它是如何发生的。幸运的是，现在期货交易。所以任何人，互联网浏览器，都可以去标普的网站查看这些股息期货的定价和交易。这很好。我们现在比刚开始这个产品或几年前在OTC市场时有更多的透明度，因为他们真的几乎非常微妙地交易。所以这很好。检查那个框。没有使用杠杆。持续地，你知道，就像投资于我可以理解的一种资产。现在的问题是，它什么时候会走向偏差？这两个市场参与者通常是如何日复一日地一起行动的？因为一个人需要卖出风险，另一个人需要买入。他们什么时候会改变主意？那将是在有巨大的结构性压力时，对吧？这将导致某种重置，这将是一个绝佳的机会。我会想知道那是一个机会，而不是某种基本面的崩溃。我如何获取这些信息？对吧？因为公司足够大到可以打电话给我吗？可能不会。所以他们足够大到在我想要谈论这个结构性问题时接电话吗？这是一个定价错误还是一个异常？然后稍微多了解一下市场。这就是我对这个产品的看法，它会有变化。会有市场重新定价的时刻。我们甚至在2016年2月看到了这种情况。我认为那是当我们看到曲线发生了某种变化，但分析师的预期没有变化，经济预期也没有变化。然而我们看到了某种平坦。所以那是一个很好的进入和购买的机会。是的。但那些机会真的很少，大约每三年一次。所以大多数情况下，这是一种产品。我认为，你知道，你开始分配，但你只需要分配更有意义的金额。这就是我想说的。我会反驳自己，我必须分配更有意义的金额。否则我只是在玩弄，你知道，我鼓励人们通常去玩弄，尝试它，开始看它，习惯它，然后再分配更多的资金给像风险降低者这样的东西。但最终，你必须。我们已经做了很多关于50 50债券债券，你知道，像债券股息类型的分配。这非常惊人。我认为，标准差大约非常低，股息的标准差也非常低，像两者都是。当你把它们放在一起时，我认为标准差降到2.5，这太棒了。我的意思是，这就是投资组合分配应该如何工作的。如果你能用这些资产做到这一点，那就太好了。
